column312: First and foremost I would like to thank those people who organized this survey.  I taik this a grassroot women led focused development organization. But our organization has become staty due to lack of committed Donors partners to work with us. This days Donors/ partners are had to get and had requirements, that Donors partners ask, sometimes grassroot women organization do lack those requirements.( Financial Audited reports,  too much paper work and other stuff. This is leading to many grassroot women organization to remain under development.  Maybe Donors partners like to develop brief Case organization because they can hire consultants to write good proposals that Donors partners like. Am wondering whether UN TRUST FUND is really committed to fund Women due to their too much paper work, and other stuff they request, a grassroot women organization could not afford to participate in their call for proposal

column312: Refugee Together For Social Transformation  .about funding we have never received any funds since we started up to date but our project is supported through our members of the organization that why we really need your support  Our mission is to empower refugees, asylum seekers and other displaced persons   around the world and to Advance Human rights by building a diverse and inclusive future for all of us    Our vision :  is to be a force for positive change and opportunity for the entire LGBTQ and the host coomunities by being a national leader in philanthropic endeavors .  Our values : Respect  .  Every person deserves respect and to be listened to  Dignity. Every person deserves dignity in policy and practice.  Equality . every person deserves equality under the law  Equity .Every person deserves equal opportunity Justice. Every person deserves justice and it is our moral imperative to ensure the fulfilment of justice  .

column312: We are finding it very frustrating to find funding. We are based in Europe and helping in Europe but most funding, even European funding, is for people doing our work in global majority countries and the US. When there is funding, the competition is FIERCE. And much funding is given by orgs that do not take unsolicited applications so it feels like funding is based on who you know and not what you do. We've also been a part of a few participatory grant making processes and found them to be hugely time consuming and also in some ways unfair. For instance, we were asked to review grants from orgs in different countries and different sectors to ours. We took hours to educate ourselves on the local contexts of those groups - but know not every group partaking in the process would have the same capacity or drive to do this

column312: The funding available to us is short term, not continuous but project based. There is little to no funds available for core support. Funds available exist for tiny and brand new collectives. Those of us who have been able to stick around do so without any support, in our free time, or as part time consultants but never granting us stability, savings, pensions, health care. The movement is so impoverished that it is not sustainable to stick around or to renew leadership within the few structures that do receive some funding. If there is money out there for women rights defenders and feminist organizing it still hasn't made its way down here.

column312: It's extremely difficult to get funding in the SWANA region, especially as an arts and culture organization not working on healthcare/humanitarian aid, particularly as the political landscape of the region gets more volatile. Additionally, many funders have their own political agendas (especially bilateral agencies that we have since learned to avoid), as the renewed international interest in the Israel-Palestine conflict has really influenced our relationship with funders who do not take a hard stance against genocide. Some have even censored our work (we have since stopped working with those donors), and we've rejected funds from prospective funders because we know better now and we will not compromise on our politics. This shuts us off from a huge amount of funding. We've also had bad experiences with the administrative & programmatic cost of projects vastly outweighing the support offered by the fund, which has really strained our team's efforts. and we had to apply for more funding just to cover salaries. Lastly, the civil society space in lebanon is extremely small and we have close contact with organizations that do receive lots of funding (over $1 million budgets), so we are keenly aware of where the money actually is! The majority of these “feminist” organizations are anti-trans and anti-sex work whose work on LGBTQIA+ is quite narrow and focused on visibility and asking for acceptance from society.

column311: Running the Community and Media Platform
column312: TMWT is a independent media platform and community centring the diverse perspectives of Muslim women. This project was started as a passion project in November 2020 with just three of us on the team. We have personally funded everything from our pockets since then, and we’ve had to pause operations because the running costs are increasing and we still haven’t gotten access to funding. We did apply for grants at intervals, but we haven’t been fortunate enough to get one. We’re looking at a paid membership model for community members and sales of merchandise to keep it afloat for now.

column289: Financiamiento flexible e institucional para la sostenibilidad de organizaciones de base feminista
column311: Sostenibilidad institucional, autocuidado, planificación colaborativa y estratégica, fortalecer investigación y generar cambios en políticas públicas según demandas juveniles.
column312: • La mayoría de las organizaciones de base no tienen una nómina, debido a fondos limitados a proyectos o a corto plazo. Tampoco hay oportunidades para capacitación técnica o financiamiento para el desarrollo de planes institucionales que permitan fortalecer el trabajo y el alcance.  • Cuando no hay un fondo central, se reproduce el trabajo no remunerado que históricamente afecta a las mujeres. Este trabajo no remunerado se transfiere de la esfera "privada" a la "comunitaria" y es "romantizado" por las agencias donantes, en lugar de ser reconocido económicamente. El activismo, la organización comunitaria y la lucha por nuestros derechos es un trabajo histórico que ha recaído en las mujeres. Estas dinámicas continúan precarizándonos.  • Se debe reconocer la diferencia en los costos de trabajar con adultos y menores. Trabajar con menores en situaciones vulnerables es más costoso porque se deben seguir muchos protocolos de seguridad, además de cubrir necesidades básicas. A veces, los donantes planifican proyectos dirigidos a menores con una idea preconcebida de trabajar con adultos. O estos costos solo se reconocen al trabajar con ONG internacionales, y no al trabajar con organizaciones de base, reproduciendo así un sistema de discriminación basado en infraestructura.  • Se debe reconocer la experiencia y el conocimiento de las organizaciones de base. La percepción del conocimiento debe ser decolonizada y no solo entendida como algo que se obtiene de la academia. No debe haber una relación condescendiente o jerárquica con nuestro trabajo, que es fundamental y clave. Cuando las grandes organizaciones se van de nuestras comunidades, somos nosotras quienes permanecemos y sostenemos el tejido comunitario.  • Todas las plataformas de financiamiento deben tener accesibilidad lingüística.  • Debe haber oportunidades de financiamiento dirigidas exclusivamente a organizaciones de base lideradas por mujeres.  • Deben existir tres tipos de fondos: Fondos centrales - enfocados en el fortalecimiento institucional (para cubrir monitoreo, comunicaciones y participación en espacios clave); Fondos a corto plazo para financiar actividades, y fondos a largo plazo para financiar proyectos (al menos dos años de implementación).  • Otras formas de apoyar a las organizaciones de base lideradas por mujeres incluyen visibilizar nuestro trabajo, conectarnos con otras oportunidades de financiamiento, capacitar a nuestro equipo y crear oportunidades de networking.

column312: Un commentaire important pour cette recherche est l'importance de la diversification des sources de financement. La dépendance à une seule source peut rendre une association vulnérable aux fluctuations économiques et aux changements de politique. Par conséquent, nous recommandons de développer une stratégie de financement variée, incluant des campagnes de collecte de fonds, l'engagement communautaire et la recherche de fonds de fondations spécialisées dans notre domaine d'activité.

column312: Para AzMina, sustentabilidade vai muito além de obtenção de recursos, mas práticas de governança, cuidado, compartilhamento e aprimoramento de conhecimentos. Financiamentos institucionais, não condicionados a projetos, são fundamentais para investirmos no planejamento da nossa área operacional e financeira, em estratégias de captação de recursos mais condizentes com a maturidade da nossa organização e com estratégias e metodologias de monitoramento e avaliação em nossas formas de trabalho e projetos. O crescimento da equipe e da estrutura da organização nos últimos quatro anos é prova irrefutável da sua competência nesse quesito. Em 2024, pela primeira vez em nossa história, estamos com uma meta de prospecção de 2 milhões de reais (cenário ideal) ou R$ 1 milhão de reais (cenário real). Com isso, toda a equipe, está especialmente envolvida em relacionamento com financiadores, viagens, abertura de novas frentes de diálogo e formatação de muitos projetos de maior impacto, em parcerias com outras organizações. Tem sido um ano desafiador, mas sem dúvidas crucial para sairmos do modelo de projetos isolados e nos dedicarmos a ações estruturantes e mobilizadas por redes com o intuito de promover impacto sistêmico.

column312: The security situation in Myanmar continues to deteriorate, with armed clashes taking place in many parts of the country. In 2024, fighting has progressively intensified particularly in Kachin State, Myanmar. Conflict, involving the deployment of heavy weapons, aerial bombardment and shooting, including in urban and populated areas, has driven a surge in displacement, civilian casualties, protection risks, and humanitarian needs. Given the scale and intensity of the unfolding crisis, affected women and girls have inter-connected, multi-dimensional needs that require a comprehensive multi-sectoral response to address survival needs and promote dignity and greater resilience. More than 3 million people are internally displaced across Myanmar, with the vast majority – more than 2.7 million – forced from their homes by conflict and insecurity since the 2021 military takeover. In Kachin State, two third of the population become internally displaced people, most of them are women and girl including most vulnerable women and girls they are pregnant mothers, breast feeding mothers, disables’ mother/wife, disable mothers, single women headed mothers have more than 3 children under 9 years. Since October 2023, the rapid spread of fighting across large swathes of the Myanmar country has propelled a drastic increase in displacement, exacerbating pre-existing needs and raising grave protection concerns. Compounding this situation is the coming monsoon season (expected between June and October) which threatens to exacerbate already dire humanitarian gender needs and vulnerabilities in many areas where displacement is highest. Against this backdrop, a timely injection of support from the HTOI Gender organization is needed to assist those recently displaced, many of whom are yet to receive any assistance due to significant underfunding and who will soon be exposed during the monsoon season. In line with the overarching strategy and priorities of the 2024 humanitarian gender needs and response plan, this allocation should provide to deliver lifesaving humanitarian assistance and services in areas with the highest levels of new or repeated displacement, prioritizing townships with the most severe needs.

column289: Los donantes deben invertir en programas con enfoque de género para abordar las causas del encarcelamiento de mujeres y promover justicia social.
column311: Pagar sueldos para hacer incidencia y visibilizar la problemática, cambiar la política criminal en el país, y dictar talleres para que las mujeres conozcan y exijan sus derechos.
column312: El tema del encarcelamiento de mujeres suele ser ignorado en el ámbito del financiamiento, como si las problemáticas vividas en privación de libertad no fueran relevantes o se tratara de un mundo aparte. La sociedad tiende a olvidar que estas mujeres, a pesar de estar en prisión, tienen derechos que deben ser respetados y garantizados. Existe una fuerte estigmatización social hacia ellas porque han roto con los roles tradicionales impuestos por la sociedad sobre lo que debe ser una mujer. Además, las organizaciones que trabajan con temas de mujeres rara vez incluyen a esta población en sus programas y políticas, perpetuando su invisibilidad y marginación.

column208: Para garantizar los Derechos Humanos de Mujeres Indígenas YUKPA y sus comunidades.

column289: Mayor acceso a las oportunidades comprendiendo los contextos, valorando los esfuerzos de organización y el compromiso de nosotras Mujeres Indígenas YUKPA de Oripanto Oayapo Tüonde
column307: Todas trabajamos en sostener nuestra organización sobre la base de un compromiso comunitario de vida con una asignación básica mensual
column311: En la Red Comunitaria de Protección de Mujeres Indígenas YUKPA de la Cuenca del Rio Yaza Sierra de Perija
column312: Nuestra experiencia es que hemos sido capaces como mujeres indígenas YUKPA, discriminadas, con muchas limitaciones de conocimiento, de organizarnos, fortalecer capacidades, generar acciones de incidencia a nivel nacional e internacional para el reconocimiento de nuestros derechos como mujeres y la justicia de género, diagnosticar necesidades, generar acciones y buenas practicas para la atención diferenciada de nuestra población comunitaria indigena con perspectiva de género, que responde al principio de localización (Grand Bargain), rindiendo cuentas y presentando proyecto con muy pocos recursos, que hemos tenido que asumir desafios para incorporarnos a la Arquitectura Humanitaria en nuestro país, para acercar la Respuesta Humanitaria a nuestro territorio y a nuestra población, estigmatizada en muchos casos por las instituciones que deben garantizar los servicios y derechos, para el fortalecimiento del  triple nexo. Con muy poco, hemos avanzado y hecho mucho más que otras organizaciones con más estructura, recursos y sobretodo  manteniendo nuestra independencia y autonomía. Hemos hecho realidad el principio El Tejido Fortalece, pues creemos, valoramos y afianzamos los vínculos con otras organizaciones nacionales e internacionales a traves del reconocimiento, respeto y la comunicación como valores fundamentales de nosotras y hacia afuera. Y ahora estamos enfocadas en crear nuestra Red Comunitaria de Protección de Mujeres Indígenas YUKPA desde el enfoque de desarrollo, paz y respuesta integral y multisectorial a las necesidades, de manera culturalmente apropiada. Con énfasis en la prevención y mitigación de la Violencia de Género

column312: Our experience with funding has often been challenging as donors typically prioritize what they perceive as urgent needs without consulting us, the front-line responders who understand the ground realities best. This disconnect is particularly evident in responding to the impacts of climate change in Iraq, where women and girls are disproportionately affected. Despite our significant efforts to raise international awareness and attract attention to this critical issue, securing the necessary funding to support these vulnerable populations remains an uphill battle. We urge funders to engage more closely with local organizations and consider our insights to ensure that resources are allocated effectively and equitably.

column312: As mentioned before, our region, the Arab Region and South Sudan, has received far below average compared to other areas in the world, research shows. Many conflicts are currently going on in our region and funders tend to bet on the safe side, or the risks of armed conflicts are too big. Funders should be bold, because so many women and girls feel left alone by the rest of the world. And we see that too, funding for our own organisation is hard and as a network in our region we hear the same from all our partners. In many conflicts violence against women increases by horrific numbers, despite this, the world of funders turns its back to our region. More transparency from funders or availability of funders would be highly appreciated. This to have a more equal resource opportunity.

This research is the platform that reflects our soul's words. We seek cooperation from feminist friend organizations.

column312: Project-based funding: Refugee Together For Social Transformation   primarily relies on project-based grants rather than core funding [Center For Forced Migrants -  Refugee Together For Social Transformation  , Strategy & Funding]. This can be limiting, as core funding provides more stability for ongoing operations. Focus on specific needs: Donors often prioritize funding specific projects, like legal representation or mental health services for refugees [Presentation -  Refugee Together For Social Transformation  ]. Challenges with core funding: Securing core funding can be difficult as donors might prefer projects with tangible outcomes [Center For Forced Migrants -  Refugee Together For Social Transformation  , Strategy & Funding]. Alternative income generation: Refugee Together For Social Transformation   uses alternative methods to generate income, like consultancy services and fees for hosting interns [Center For Forced Migrants -  Refugee Together For Social Transformation  , Strategy & Funding].Sustainability: Explore ways to secure core funding alongside project-based grants for long-term stability. Demonstrating impact: Clearly outline the project's impact on refugees' lives to attract funding. Diversifying income: Consider alternative income streams like workshops or partnerships.

column311: Global Media Monitoring Project (GMMP)-2025 and staff recruiting
column312: Global Media Monitoring Project (GMMP)-2025 is first undertaken in 1995, captured baseline data on crucial gender equality indicators in the news media. The next edition of the project planned for 2025 will gather insights on the state of play 30 years later, contributing evidence to the status of the implementation of Section J of the Beijing Platform for Action three decades since its adoption. Specific Objectives  The specific objectives of the 2025 GMMP are as follows:  i.	To build capacity of civil society groups engaged in women’s rights or gender equality work, media professionals, students and others to carry out participatory media monitoring with a gender lens. ii.	To update the data on the status of gender equality in the news media 30 years after Beijing, expanding the time series dataset commenced in 1995. To collect baseline data from countries for which data have not been gathered. So far, the GMMP dataset spans 163 countries with data points across a 25-year period, and with at least one observation for each variable and country.  iii.	To gather new data on the global top priority concerns of the day. News topics identified for special attention are: a.	Climate change  b.	Women politicians and political aspirants c.	Gender-based violence d.	Peace, security and conflict iv.	To gather insights on how Technology-Facilitated Gender-Based Violence (TFGBV) plays out on news platforms through a monitoring of user feedback and comments beneath news stories published online. v.	To draw lessons for the news media industry on the opportunities that a gender, diversity and inclusion orientation presents to navigate the current crises and to build long-term viability. To develop specific, actionable recommendations and a basket of levers of progress towards gender equality in the news industry.

column312: My experiences are very long but I want to tell them to you in short.My name is Neetu and I am from India. I am a handicapped woman. I struggled a lot in my childhood due to my disability. I could not study. I always stayed at home and could never go out and I was also abused.And my rights were also violated. I struggled a lot due to disability. I have a lot of experiences, but I cannot talk about all of them, but today I am moving forward with all those experiences and doing social work. I do not have any funding from anywhere for women and disabled women. I am running my organization by somehow collecting some funding from around me. I want to say this much about this research. It is a good platform from where organizations, funding types and good work can be done. Thank you so much for including me in this survey.

column311: Fortalecimiento de la autonomía corporal de niñas y adolescentes para prevenir violencias sexuales y trata de personas.
column312: Como pequeña organización y de trabajo de base muchas veces se hace dificil hacer atención e incidencia en política pública por falta de recursos económicos y de compañeras que puedan ser contratadas con salarios justos. Creo que ahora los donantes buscan que se hagan las tres áreas de trabajo pero no colaboran con un donativo que sostenga de manera digna el trabajo en cuestión de paga y de sostenimiento en el tiempo. Buscan que las organizaciones seamos sostenibles, sin embargo las actividades que se hacen nunca se cobran pues la gente con quienes trabajamos se encuentran en situaciones de vulnerabilidad. Pocas veces contamos con el tiempo y personal para pensar en actividades que permitan la venta de productos, lo que nos dificulta ese tema. Las agendas cambian constantemente y esto hace que seamos flexibles y resilientes , sin embargo nos quemamos muy rápido. Muchas veces por conseguir los financiamientos nos da miedo preguntar las prioridades en cuanto al número de participantes en los proyectos; ¡se ve bien que hagamos muchos número con poco recurso o será que les interesa que sean pocos beneficiarios con mayor numero de capacidades? Este tipo de incertidumbres suceden mucho, ellos tienen el dinero y muchas veces el poder lo que en ocasiones a las organizaciones nos hace sentir que debemos de responder a sus exigencias. Cotidianamente dejamos lo importante por lo urgente, dejamos de profesionalizarnos, de cuidarnos, de actualizarnos, de ser personas por estar respondiendo a las agendas.   Una cosa importante es que en realidad quienes estamos haciendo el trabajo de base somos quienes estamos en contacto con la verdadera realidad, no con números o estadísticas sino con las vidas; es prioridad atender este tipo de organizaciones frente a la incidencia en política pública. También agradecer quienes están en esos lugares que han elegido dar la lucha desde allí, pero que jamás olviden a quienes la damos en el territorio y no en los escritorios.

column312: As a mid-sized fundraising and programme-delivery organisation, we apply for grants from trusts, foundations and corporations, as well as relying on individual donations. Our most successful long-term funders have formed a relationship with us that transcends funding or application requirements. We are finding it more challenging to have successful applications through traditional channels (ie, find an application, complete it, send it in). We are shifting our focus to being more visible and encouraging funders to approach us. This allows us to run projects with our in-country partners in India, Nepal and Bangladesh. We imagine that the challenge for smaller grassroots organisations is even greater (this is certainly true for our in-country partners when fundraising individually), and recognise the need for more resources to support them access funds.

column289: We urge funders to provide flexible, unrestricted funding to help organizations cover operational costs, invest in capacity building, and pursue long-term advocacy and systemic change.
column311: We would spend the money on covering core operational costs, capacity building for our staff and volunteers, and enhancing our technological infrastructure to better manage and expand our programs.
column312: Our experience with funding has highlighted several critical challenges. While we appreciate the support we've received for specific projects, the lack of unrestricted funding has constrained our ability to cover essential operational costs and invest in long-term capacity building. Additionally, the competitive nature of funding often diverts our focus from impactful advocacy and systemic change efforts to short-term, project-specific goals. We urge funders to recognize the importance of flexible funding that supports not only the direct outcomes but also the sustainability and growth of the organizations driving these initiatives. Investing in core operations, infrastructure, and strategic development is crucial for fostering resilient and effective movements.

column312: Se necesita diversificar los fondos para aquellas organizaciones que nunca hemos recibido fondos feministas o de derechos de mujeres, quitando barreras de entradas y estableciendo una relación fuera de las lógicas de proyectos y programas, para que las organizaciones puedan crecer, no solo en cuanto a procesos de incidencia, sino de estabilidad laboral. El tener recursos solo enfocado a proyectos nos restringe derechos y libertades en nuestro trabajo, que muchas veces es amenazado. Por ejemplo, nuestra organización tiene una amenaza por nuestra labor en la defensa de los derechos.

column312: In 2008, we initiated the LBT movement in the Far West in Nepal and officially registered our organization as an NGO in 2009. We are the only organization working on LBT issues in the far western province of Nepal. While working at a grassroots level, we faced challenges in fundraising and proposal writing and did not receive any support from external donors until 2022. It was only in 2022, with the help of some colleagues, that we received funding for a year from Women Fund Asia. Unfortunately, donors often overlook organizations working at remote grassroots levels. Therefore, we kindly request that donors consider supporting grassroots organizations, as they have a deep understanding of the needs and situations of marginalized populations and can bring positive change.

column289: Пожелание донорам: постараться не ограничивать работу организации своими рамками, абсолютно не понимая контекста и знаяо нем лишь от внешних источников, а не от самих финансируемых организаций.
column311: Оплата труда 3 сотрудниц, бухгалтерки, регистрация юридического лица и оплата основной деятельности
column312: Наша организация сейчас занимается доступом трансгендерных людей к сулугам здравоохранения. В России с 2023 года полностью запрещен трансгендерный переход. Нам необходимо заниматься регулярными мониторингом, исследованиями положения трансгендерных людей, однако абсолютно всефоны отказывают в проведении исследований. Вторая наша задача - научная деятельность. Не просто абстрактная, а деятельность, направленная на восполнение научной информации о трансгендерных людях, которую преднамеренно учничтожает государство. Однако слово "наука" и "исследование" вызывают алергию у доноров, которые не понимают контекста.  Наша задача, связанная с наукой, - адвокационная, восполняющая недостаток информации для трансгендерных людей, специалистов в области медицины, ВИЧ и т.п. Кроме того, из-за специафики работы с сфере медицины и здравоохранения, мы постоянно находимся на связи с медицинским сообществом, которое не готово слушать активистов, но открыто к коллегам, говорящим на их языке. Этот контекст тоже никому не ясен, но ни один из доноров и не делал попытку узнать подробнее о том, чем мы занимаемся и почему это важно. Понимание мы находим, только если среди представителей доноров есть люди из России или связанные с ней.

Además de que nos fortalece y nos permite crecer.

column311: Salaries, strategizing, emergency support and actions, capacity building
column312: Since our creation (2022) we only received funding from FRIDA Feminist Fund and the European Network Against Racism. Until 2024 spring we were unregistered and we had very little opportunities to apply for funding. We applied for several things, but we were continuously rejected. Roma feminists are their agendas are not supported neither in mainstream European or in feminist philantrophic organizations. We need a Roma Feminist Fund which would support initatives with core funding so that the movements can build up and strategize. Without that we will achieve very little, as we are burnt out in working for free and receiving no appreciaton and acknowledgement for our work. Please, take this message forward and reach out to us if you think we can collaborate together in the creating of a Roma Feminist Fund, or if you could support us and other Roma feminist initatives. Thank you!

column311: ORGANISATIONS GOALS
column312: Peer Review for Grants: Peer review is essential for evaluating research proposals submitted to funding agencies. It ensures rigorous assessment of scientific merit and quality. An exploratory study1 investigated the skills necessary for effective peer reviewers on grant review panels. These skills include critical analysis, communication, and understanding of funding agency priorities. Reviewer experience and the use of technology impact skill development. Whether in-person or virtual, effective peer review requires expertise and attention to detail. Navigating Research Funding: Researchers seeking funding should explore available opportunities. Understanding grant mechanisms, eligibility criteria, and application processes is crucial. A comprehensive guide2 can help you navigate the intricate world of research funding and grants. It covers various aspects, from proposal writing to budgeting. Feedback and Grantsmanship: Grant applicants receive feedback during the review process. Constructive feedback helps improve proposals. Expert reviewers provide margin comments and key recommendations to enhance grantsmanship and compliance3. Reviewer Expertise: Reviewer expertise significantly influences decision-making in peer review. Although peer review is the gold standard for evaluating research, it’s essential to recognize its limitations and continually improve the process.
